metadata.product: Gabrylly Ergonomic Mesh Office Chair, High Back Desk Chair

transcript.speaker: **Customer Interview
transcript.text: Gabrylly Ergonomic Mesh Office Chair**

transcript.speaker: **Interviewer
transcript.text: ** Sarah (Corporate Representative)

transcript.speaker: **Interviewee
transcript.text: ** Kelly (Customer) ---

transcript.speaker: **Sarah
transcript.text: ** Good morning, Kelly. Thank you so much for taking the time to speak with me today. My name is Sarah, and I’m with Gabrylly’s product feedback team. We really appreciate you sharing your experience with our ergonomic mesh office chair, and we want to understand it more deeply to help us improve.

transcript.speaker: **Kelly
transcript.text: ** Good morning, Sarah. Yeah, no problem. I’m happy to, uh, you know, share my thoughts. Honestly, I’m glad someone’s actually following up.

transcript.speaker: **Sarah
transcript.text: ** Absolutely. Your feedback is incredibly valuable to us. Before we dive into the specifics of the chair, could you tell me a little bit about what prompted you to look for a new office chair in the first place? What was your previous setup like?

transcript.speaker: **Kelly
transcript.text: ** Sure. So, my old chair… it was a gaming chair, actually. You know, one of those big, bucket-seat ones with the faux leather. I’d had it for probably five or six years, and it was just… falling apart. The armrests were ripped, the foam in the seat was completely compressed, and it creaked constantly. I spend a *lot* of time at my desk, sometimes 8 to 12 hours a day, so it was really essential to get something better.

transcript.speaker: **Sarah
transcript.text: ** Wow, 8 to 12 hours is quite significant. And you mentioned "gaming" and also "coding and studying" in your review. Could you elaborate a bit on what that daily routine looks like for you at your desk?

transcript.speaker: **Kelly
transcript.text: ** Yeah, so I’m a store manager, which keeps me busy during the day, but in the evenings and on weekends, I’m really into gaming – like, competitive stuff, strategy games, RPGs. And I’m also, um, taking some online computer science courses, just for my own interest, you know? Keeping the brain active. So, I’m not exactly a full-time student, but I’m doing a lot of coding projects and studying after work. It’s a mix, really.

transcript.speaker: **Sarah
transcript.text: ** That makes a lot of sense. So, given that you spend so much time there, you were looking for a significant upgrade. When you started looking for a new chair, what were the key things you were hoping to find? What criteria were most important to you?

transcript.speaker: **Kelly
transcript.text: ** Well, comfort was obviously number one. But beyond that, I really wanted something *ergonomic*. My old gaming chair, while it looked cool, wasn’t really designed for proper posture or long-term health. I was starting to get back pain and shoulder stiffness. I also wanted something durable. I figured if I was going to invest in a chair, it should last more than a year or two. And, honestly, something that looked a bit more… mature, I guess? Less like a race car seat. Your chair, the Gabrylly, seemed to tick those boxes. It was mesh, looked supportive, and wasn’t super expensive but not super cheap either. It felt like a reasonable mid-range option.

transcript.speaker: **Sarah
transcript.text: ** I see. And did you consider any other specific brands or types of chairs during your search? Perhaps another gaming chair or something even higher-end?

transcript.speaker: **Kelly
transcript.text: ** Hmm, good question. I looked at a few other mesh chairs online, some of the more… well, the really expensive ones, like Herman Miller, but those were just out of my budget, honestly. I thought about another gaming chair, but I really wanted to move away from the aesthetic and the typical materials. I saw some other brands that were similar to Gabrylly, but I honestly can’t remember the names now. Yours just seemed to have a good balance of features and reviews, at the time, that looked promising.

transcript.speaker: **Sarah
transcript.text: ** Okay, so you made the purchase, and then came the assembly. In your review, you mentioned the instructions were minimal and screw holes didn't align perfectly. Could you walk me through that experience a bit?

transcript.speaker: **Kelly
transcript.text: ** Oh, yeah, the assembly. That was… an experience. The instructions were basically just diagrams, which is fine, but they weren't always super clear on orientation. I remember specifically with the backrest, it took a bit of fiddling. And then, like I said, some of the screw holes, especially for the armrests, just weren’t quite lining up. I had to really… um… force it. Like, lean into it to get the screws to catch. I was worried I was going to strip something. It felt a bit like a cheap IKEA product, not something I’d just paid a few hundred dollars for.

transcript.speaker: **Sarah
transcript.text: ** That sounds frustrating right out of the gate. And you mentioned the armrests felt wobbly even after assembly. Was that noticeable immediately?

transcript.speaker: **Kelly
transcript.text: ** Yes, immediately. They clicked into place, but there was always a bit of play, you know? Like they weren’t quite snug. It wasn’t just a little wobble; it was enough that if I leaned on them to shift my weight, I felt them give a bit. It didn’t inspire confidence in the overall build.

transcript.speaker: **Sarah
transcript.text: ** I can certainly understand that. So, you got it assembled and started using it. You mentioned the mesh back was a nice change. What were your initial impressions of the breathability compared to your old chair?

transcript.speaker: **Kelly
transcript.text: ** Oh, that was definitely a plus. My old chair, with the faux leather, it was a sweat trap, especially during long gaming sessions or in the summer. The mesh back on the Gabrylly was genuinely breathable. I didn’t get that sweaty back feeling, which was a huge relief. That was probably the one consistent positive, honestly.

transcript.speaker: **Sarah
transcript.text: ** That’s good to hear, at least for one aspect. Now, let's talk about the seat. You described it as "incredibly firm and unforgiving" and causing pressure points and tailbone aching. Can you tell me more about that? How quickly did you start to notice this discomfort?

transcript.speaker: **Kelly
transcript.text: ** Pretty quickly. After about an hour, maybe an hour and a half, I’d start to feel it. It wasn’t like sitting on a rock, exactly, but it just had no give. My old gaming chair, for all its flaws, had a plush, albeit compressed, seat. This one… it felt like there was a very thin layer of padding over a hard surface. And because I’m sitting there for so long, alternating between coding where I’m leaning forward, and gaming where I’m more upright, it just really dug into my tailbone and the backs of my thighs. It was awful. I tried adding a cushion, but then that messed up the whole ergonomic idea.

transcript.speaker: **Sarah
transcript.text: ** That completely defeats the purpose of an ergonomic chair if you need an additional cushion. And regarding the headrest, you mentioned it was a "joke" for anyone over 5'8", and you're 5'10". How did that manifest in your daily use?

transcript.speaker: **Kelly
transcript.text: ** Yeah, it just… didn't reach. At its absolute highest setting, it barely touched the very base of my skull, where my neck meets my head. It offered no actual *support* for my head or neck. If I wanted to lean back and rest my head, I had to physically slouch down in the chair, which is the opposite of what you want for good posture. It felt like it was designed for someone significantly shorter than me, which is frustrating because 5'10" isn't exactly giant.

transcript.speaker: **Sarah
transcript.text: ** I hear you. It sounds like a critical miss on the adjustability there. And the armrests – aside from the wobbling, you mentioned they lacked swivel, which you feel is essential for gaming ergonomics. Could you explain why that feature is so important for your use case?

transcript.speaker: **Kelly
transcript.text: ** Absolutely. When you’re gaming, especially with a keyboard and mouse, you need your forearms to be supported, but your arms also need a natural range of motion. With fixed armrests, or just height-adjustable ones, you can’t really get them in the ideal position relative to your desk and keyboard tray. Sometimes I like to bring them in a bit, or angle them out. The lack of swivel meant my arms were always at a slightly awkward angle, which contributed to shoulder fatigue. My old gaming chair, even though it was cheap, had some basic swivel, and I really missed that. It felt like a step backward, not forward, ergonomically.

transcript.speaker: **Sarah
transcript.text: ** That’s a very specific and important insight for gamers. So, for the first couple of months, despite these comfort and adjustability issues, you continued to use the chair. But then, as you described, there were catastrophic failures. Can you tell me exactly what happened with the wheels and the base?

transcript.speaker: **Kelly
transcript.text: ** Ugh, this is the worst part. Within, I’d say, two months, maybe a little less, one of the plastic wheel housings cracked. Not the wheel itself, but the plastic piece it slots into on the base. I’m not a heavy person, I’m 170 pounds, and I don’t abuse my chairs. I just roll it back and forth a few feet on my hardwood floor, from my desk to my file cabinet. Then, about a week or two later, another wheel snapped off completely. It just… detached. Sent me listing to one side. It was genuinely startling.

transcript.speaker: **Sarah
transcript.text: ** Oh my goodness. That sounds like a very alarming experience. And then the base itself began to crack?

transcript.speaker: **Kelly
transcript.text: ** Yes! Shortly after the second wheel snapped, I noticed the entire star-shaped base was cracking. Right near where the hydraulic cylinder inserts. It started as a hairline crack and just spread. It was clearly made of some really brittle, flimsy plastic. I mean, my old cheap gaming chair had a metal base. This was supposed to be an *upgrade*. Now, three months in, it’s completely unusable. It wobbles, it tilts, it’s genuinely dangerous to sit on. I had to pull out my old, broken gaming chair just to have something.

transcript.speaker: **Sarah
transcript.text: ** That’s completely unacceptable, Kelly. I’m so sorry to hear you went through that. It sounds like the material quality of the base and wheels was far below expectations. When you say "flimsy, brittle plastic," were you expecting something different based on the product description or images?

transcript.speaker: **Kelly
transcript.text: ** Definitely. The pictures online, and the whole "ergonomic office chair" branding, gives the impression of something robust and solid. I expected either a sturdy metal base, or at least a very high-grade, reinforced nylon, like you’d see on a proper office chair. This felt like… cheap toy plastic. It just didn’t match the perceived quality or the price point.

transcript.speaker: **Sarah
transcript.text: ** I understand. You mentioned the price point earlier. Given your experience, how do you now perceive the value of this chair?

transcript.speaker: **Kelly
transcript.text: ** Honestly? Terribly. For what I paid, it should have lasted years, not three months. It felt like I paid for an ergonomic design that didn't actually deliver comfort, and a build quality that was dangerously subpar. I wish I had just saved a bit more for a truly high-end chair, or honestly, just bought another cheap gaming chair because at least those are designed for heavy use, even if they aren't 'ergonomic.' The value proposition just isn’t there at all.

transcript.speaker: **Sarah
transcript.text: ** That’s very clear. So, if you could wave a magic wand and change three things about this Gabrylly chair to make it a five-star product for someone like you, what would those three things be?

transcript.speaker: **Kelly
transcript.text: ** Okay, hmm. First, definitely the *seat*. It needs to be significantly softer and more supportive, with proper padding that doesn't cause pressure points. That's paramount for long hours. Second, the *base and wheels* need a complete overhaul. They need to be made of a robust material – metal, or extremely high-grade, reinforced composite – that can actually withstand normal use without cracking and breaking. It’s a safety issue. And third, the *armrests* need to be fully adjustable, including a swivel function, and they need to be rock-solid, no wobble. Oh, and if I get a fourth, make the *headrest* actually work for people over 5'8". That’s more than three, but those are all critical for me.

transcript.speaker: **Sarah
transcript.text: ** Those are all very concrete and actionable suggestions, Kelly, thank you. You've clearly thought a lot about what would make this chair truly functional for your needs. Given everything we’ve discussed, would you ever consider purchasing a Gabrylly chair again, assuming these issues were addressed in future models?

transcript.speaker: **Kelly
transcript.text: ** That’s… a tough one. My trust is pretty shaken, honestly. I think I’d have to see a lot of incredibly strong, independent reviews and perhaps a very robust warranty that specifically addresses the durability concerns. But even then, I’d be very, very hesitant. The experience of having a chair break like that, and feeling unsafe, really leaves a bad taste.

transcript.speaker: **Sarah
transcript.text: ** I can completely understand that hesitation. And on the flip side, what would make you confidently switch to a competitor, or what features would draw you away from Gabrylly if you were looking for a chair today?

transcript.speaker: **Kelly
transcript.text: ** Well, what would draw me away is exactly what happened: poor quality that leads to breakage, and discomfort that makes long hours unbearable. What would draw me to a competitor would be a proven track record for durability, genuine ergonomic support that accommodates taller users, and materials that feel substantial and safe. I’d probably prioritize chairs with metal bases and highly adjustable components, even if it meant paying a bit more upfront. I learned my lesson about trying to find a "value" ergonomic chair that ends up being a safety hazard.

transcript.speaker: **Sarah
transcript.text: ** Thank you for being so candid, Kelly. This has been incredibly insightful. We truly appreciate you taking the time to share such detailed feedback with us. It gives us a lot to consider as we look at product improvements. Just one final question to wrap things up: On a scale of 1 to 10, with 1 being extremely dissatisfied and 10 being extremely satisfied, how would you rate your overall experience with the Gabrylly Ergonomic Mesh Office Chair?

transcript.speaker: **Kelly
transcript.text: ** Hmm, given everything… the initial frustrations, the discomfort, and then the catastrophic failure that made it unusable and unsafe… I’d have to say a **1**. Maybe even a 0 if that were an option, but I guess the breathable back was okay for a minute. So, a 1.

transcript.speaker: **Sarah
transcript.text: ** Thank you for that honest rating, Kelly. We really do take all feedback seriously, and yours is particularly important in understanding where we need to make significant changes. We will be sure to share all of your comments directly with our product development and quality assurance teams. Thank you again for your time today.

transcript.speaker: **Kelly
transcript.text: ** You’re welcome, Sarah. I hope it helps.
